abstract.p: National Federation of Croatian Americans director John P Kraljic, in response to Oct 15 article, says not pressing new Yugoslav government to turn over war criminals in order to promote its stabilization may have effect of bringing even greater instability to region, especially to Croatia

block.p: Re ''The Serbs Ask a Chance to Judge Their Own Guilt'' (Week in Review, Oct. 15):

Not pressing the new Yugoslav government to turn over war criminals in order to promote its stabilization may have the effect of bringing even greater instability to the region, especially to Croatia.
Re ''The Serbs Ask a Chance to Judge Their Own Guilt'' (Week in Review, Oct. 15):

Not pressing the new Yugoslav government to turn over war criminals in order to promote its stabilization may have the effect of bringing even greater instability to the region, especially to Croatia.

Croatia's firmly established democratic government carried out practically all of its obligations toward the International War Crimes Tribunal in The Hague, and has aggressively pursued those individuals accused of committing crimes against ethnic Serbs in Croatia.

Allowing Yugoslavia and Serbia to escape the same obligations while granting them enormous financial rewards generates cynicism among Croats and provides fodder to right-wing extremists in Croatia who want the country to turn its back on Europe and engage in expansionist adventures in Bosnia.
JOHN P. KRALJIC Flushing, Queens, Oct. 15, 2000
The writer is on the board of directors of the National Federation of Croatian Americans.
